there's often a lot of back and forward
there's a lot of following up so this
platform will just say like I want to go
for the Chicago water department for
these records it will send automatic
follow-ups it will host your documents
want to get them it's really nice and
it's really like it's kind of like the
standard of what we would hope awfully a
record-keeping would be like even unlock
on a government level but it's not so
you know they kind of fit that need our
project is about civil asset forfeiture
is anyone familiar with that so it's so
civil asset forfeiture is a program that
allows your property to be seized it
could be cash it could be our car it's
usually cash or cars if you've been
suspected of a crime um you don't have
to prove that a person is like guilty
you know how to be you don't even have
to be charged with a crime to be to have
your property seized so what we've done
is we've analyzed five years moving into
the sixth year now all of the
expenditures that the Chicago Police
Department has done with that money on
so we found two surprising things the
first is that or maybe not surprising
the first is that it funds a lot of
everyday operations of the police
department like you know phones for
undercover drug buys things like car
repairs for seized vehicles things that
would normally come out of a police
budget if anyone was looking or asking
questions
the other thing that we found was that a
lot of the surveillance programs that we
find are funded through a forfeiture so
like automatic license plate readers
cell site simulators things like that so
that was another thing that we found and
we're working with Joe Hanley and the
Chicago Reader could publish our
investigation in the next month or two
we're going to have our first article
out about this stuff and so if you're

yeah yeah so secure drop is a free and
open source software project that hopes
to make this whistle blowing process
easier so it was a project that was
originally written by the late Aaron
Swartz and is currently written and
maintained by the freedom of the press
foundation which is a nonprofit that
tries to use tech and journalism
together so the goal of this project is
to reduce risk to sources when they want
to leak information to journalists so
increasingly there is more risk to
sources because of the amount of data
collection that's occurring you don't
need to go to a journalist and say hey
who is your source if you can just get a
court order for that journalists cell
phone records for example and this is
something that has been done and so this
is the goal of secured rob to reduce
that metadata as much as is possible so
it's an anonymous whistleblowing system
that uses tour which is an anonymity
system to ensure the anonymity of the
source and along with that comes no
logging so the landing pages for secure
drop don't log any information about
your browser there's no third-party
tracking on the pages and the source
interface itself runs as a tor hidden
service which is a way to anonymize the
server and the client so another feature
of secure drop is that all the documents
that are submitted are encrypted both in
transit and in rest so if for example
law enforcement were to raid the
location of the secure drop servers all
of the source documents are kept
encrypted and thus the anonymity of the
source is protected so this is the
architecture of secure drop so if a
source wanted to leak a document to
secure drop they would go through tor
and they would access it's just a simple
web application which will show you what
it looks like in a second and the goal
is to make it as easy as possible for
people to leave this data so it's really
easy and then a journalist can come
later can check on the server see if
anything has been uploaded and they can
take some documents to an air-gapped
machines and egg up machine is one that
is never totally touch the internet and
so it's a safe space to work with these
documents and
if a journalist wants to take these
documents and write a story about it
they can then strip off the metadata
that may identify the source and then
you know put them on the internet for
everyone to see so there are 25 of these
that are publicly deployed right now in
the world including ours including these
places Washington Post the intercept the
new yorker ProPublica and there's a full
list on secure drop dot org slash
directory so if you want to see all of
the organizations many are media
organizations but there are also
nonprofits like guys that are trying to
do this so this is what the sauce
interface look alikes is just like a
simple flask web app so if you're coming
to the first time to the page you can
just click this to submit documents and
to get to this point all you need to do
is go to tor project org and download
the tor browser bundle which is a
special web browser that enables you to
use this tool anonymity network and we
have a page that describes some of the
other security concerns that you might
want to be aware of if you were to do
this and then another thing that sources
can do through this interface is talk
with journalists so if you want to have
a way that a journalist can talk to
someone who has some privileged access
without the journalist maybe even being
aware of the sources identity this is a
